--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> One thing to consider about speciation is that it
> goes hand in hand 
> with complexification.  In other words, speciation
> facilitates starting the entire population with a 
> very small genome and 
> complexifying from there.  But if you *don't* start
> that way, then 
> the effects of speciation are questionable, since
> many of the 
> species will be protected without justification just
> because they 
> happen to be in the initial population.  Does your
> system start minimally?

I tend to agree with you, Ken...but I'm just thinking
out loud here.

My impression is that speciation, as implemented in
NEAT, is meant to protect innovation.  Innovation does
not necessarily have to be complexification, does it?

If you had a speciated population of complex
solutions, with subtractive mutations that actually
remove or disable parts of the genome, an innovation
might actually be a simplification of how a given
neural structure functions, right?  

If there is a simplifying trend that might actually
lead to increased fitness, you would also want to
protect that group of genotypes by speciating them.

This is analogous to nature, isn't it?  There is a
general trend of complexification, but in certain
niches and within particular populations, a
simplification of morphological structure could arise
as a mutation and actually increase the fitness of
that individual.

It seems that starting minimally and complexifying
makes a lot of sense in the early stages of a given
run, but perhaps in a long run, during the mid to late
stages, simplification may be an important dynamic to
add, and speciation may work to protect simplified
innovations just as it worked to protect complexified
innovations early in the run.

However, I'd agree that if you start with a random
population full of complex solutions, speciation is
probably going to be much less useful.  I don't know,
though...it's a very interesting area to explore.

Derek
